handDesc.p: Halantas. Final M looks rather like a check mark, at head height. Final T looks like a slightly reduced ta, possibly with a different stroke in place of its headmark (l18, l34). Final N is a slightly simplified na without a headmark (l26). Rare final Ḷ in l28-29 (3 times) and l37. All instances of the latter are unclear; those in l28-29 seem like regular ḷa with a curved horizontal stroke attached to the head, while that in l37 appears to be a reduced ḷa with a curved vertical stroke in place of a headmark.
Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is normally on top of the character to which it belongs, but occasionally (l19 muṁjuṇūru: only in vernacular words?) atop the next character.

projectDesc.p: This project DHARMA has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement no 809994).

prefixDef.p: Public URIs with the prefix bib to point to a Zotero Group Library named ERC-DHARMA whose data are open to the public.
Internal URIs using the part prefix to point to person elements in the DHARMA_IdListMembers_V01.xml file.

div.head: Plates
div.p:
śrīmatāM sakala-bhuvana-saṁstūyamāna-mānavya-sago
traāṇāM hārīti-putrāṇāM svāmi-mahāsena-paādānudhyā
tānāM kauśīikī-vara-prasāda-labdha-rājyaānāM bhagavan-nārāyanṇa-pra
sāda-samāsādita-varāha-lāñchanekṣaṇa-kṣaṇa-vaśīkrir̥tāśeṣa
mahībhr̥tāṁ Aśvamedhāvabhr̥tha-snāna-pavitrīkri̥r̥ta-mānasa-śarīrā
ṇāM sva-yaśo-viṣayīkrir̥ta-trailokyānāM caḷukyānāM ku
lam alaṁkrir̥tya nija-janmanaḥā virājamānāḥasya śrī-kīrttivarmma-mahā
rājasya naptā śrī-viṣṇuvarddhana-mahārājaḥsya raṇa-mukha-gata-ripu
-vijaya-samupalabdha-śrī-vadhū-nivāsāyamāna-vipula-vakṣaaḥ-sthala
sya putraḥ śakti-traya-samadhigata-mahā-khyāti-vibhūtiḥ tri
vargga-sevā-nipuṇaḥ purāṇa-puruṣa Iva bahu-loka-stu
taḥ purārātir iva bhūta-gaṇa-priyaḥ dvitīya Iva makaradhvajaḥ
pañcama Iva lokapālaḥ pridhagrapr̥thāgra-suta Iva satya-sandhaḥ śarāat-kāla Iva
kr̥ta-bandhu-jīvotsavaḥ pūrvvācaloendra Iva mitrodayānukūla
-mahimāaḥ mahīpati-makuṭa-taṭa-ghaṭita-mahā-ratna-marīci-ma
ñjarī-rañjita-caraṇāravinda-yugaḷlaḥ śrīndravarmma-mahārājaḥ tyā
ga-dhenyāv-apara-nāma-dheyaḥ Udaka-pūrvvakaṁ sarvva-karā!a-parihāropetaM
brahmadaeyīkr̥tya koṇḍaṇagūru-nāma grāmagrāmaM prādāT

tasya grāmasya
dig-vibhāgāḥ| Uttarataḥ muṁjuṇūru-nāma grāmaḥ. pūrvvataḥ pagunūru-nāma grā
maḥ. dakṣiṇa-vibhāgaāvasthitaḥ ceṟupūru-nāma grāmaḥ. paścimataḥ Irbu
li-nāma graāmaḥ. Eteṣāṁ grāmāṇāṁ maddhyeṁ nivaāsī-kr̥taḥ. vājasaneya-ca
raṇasya durggaśarmmaṇaḥ brahma-vihita-karmma-niratasya Iṟṟaḷūr-boya-nāma
brāhmaṇasya pautrāya Abhijana-vīidyā-vrir̥ttavataḥ bhāradvāja-sagotra
sya viṣṇuśarmmaṇaḥ putrāya vedavid-vipra-saṁstūyamāna-caritāya
ceṇḍiśarmmaṇe mātā-pitror ātmanaś ca puṇyoāvāptaye

Iti ca
bhāvino rājarṣīN yathopacāra-purassaraM sammānayati

Āryyā
hū-vaṁśa-gagana-tilaka-bhūta-rkoṇḍivarmmaṇo mahārājasyāgra-suta-I
ndravarmmaṇa-nāma-dheya-viñjjñāpanayā. tasyāñjājñaptir oevaM Ālapāka-boḶ
ppi-boḶ somayājula-veḷḷekki-boḶ māraṭa-boḶ

Api ca mohāl lobhā
d vā yaẖ kaścid vighna-karttāra sa pañca-mahāpātaka-yukto bhaviṣyati. Iti ca
veda-vyāsasya ślokaāś cātra

app.note: Hultzsch's edition prints literally mahībhr̥itām[=*], which I interpret to mean that he reads a final M here and normalises to m (in an akṣara with the following a). In the facsimile the text seems to have an anusvāra.

I accept Huntzsch's reading, shown as unclear in his edition, but cannot confirm it from the facsimile, in which nothing can be made out here. It seems possible that four rather than three characters were engraved here.

Hultzsch offers both of his emendations tentatively. I agree with the first (though it is also possible that the composer's intent had been alaṁkr̥ta-nija-janmanaḥ), but disagree with the second, which I prefer to emend so that it agrees with kīrttivarmma-mahārājasya.
I accept Hultzsch's reading, but the last character looks in the estampage rather like a vertical bar rather.
The anusvāra is on top of ju, but I assume it is to be read after mu.

In the estampage, the last character in line 20 is almost certainly rbu, not rbba. The village Irbuli is mentioned in line 11 of the Kopparam plates of Pulakeśin II as being in proximity to the village Koṇḍaceṟupūr, which I believe is identical to the Ceṟupūru of the present grant.

The l in EH's edition is probably a typo, since the consonant is clear in the estampage. The subscript of that consonant may perhaps be a second consonant, but it is most likely the vocalisation ū as read by Hultzsch.
Here too I accept EH's reading, but cannot confirm it from the estampage. There may have been only two characters engraved here.

Hultzsch construes these words with the preceding sentence, but to me the lack of sandhi before them, as well as the context, suggest that they go with the following one. See the translation for my interpretation.
Could āryyāhva have been intended here? The vowel at the end of line 23 may also be o instead of ā.

I think the ṇ at the end of this word has a quite clear second vowel stroke attached at the bottom left. See the note to the translation on how Hultzsch interprets this passage and how I differ from him. The first character of the name looks like ro in the estampage; if it was indended for ko, then it has no headmark. The second character may have been corrected from something else. Its consonants are probably intended to be ṇḍ, but ḍ is attached to the right of ṇ rather than to the bottom (as e.g. in l25, ceṇḍiśarmmaṇe). The vowel marker includes a second curved stroke to the left of a recognisable i.

I feel quite sure that all of this sequence describes the petitioner, so the words are technically in compound (in fact simply being used without case endings). See the note to the translation on how Hultzsch interprets this passage and how I differ from him. Hultzsch's nama may be a typo in the edition, since the ā is the clearest part of the character nā; his emendation concerns the locus as a whole, not this particular character. In the facsimile, I see nothing of Hultzsch's ṇa. The damaged space is slightly wider than expected for ṇa, but I assume that Hultzsch read this character correctly. If so, this genitive ending, though syntactically incorrect here, is nonetheless in my opinion an indication that I am correct to interpret all of this stretch as a description of the petitioner.

See the note to the translation on how Hultzsch interprets this passage and how I differ from him. There is in fact a dot at median height after this word, which may be a punctuation mark or the remnant of one.

Hultzsch construes Iti ca with the preceding sentence, but to me the lack of sandhi before these words, as well as the context, suggest that they go with the following one. See the translation for my interpretation.

div.p: The opening text svasti level with (or slightly above) line 2 of the body text, placed on the left (beginning around 1 o' clock of the binding hole), so that the body text of line 2 is indented by about 3 character widths.

On most pages, lines next to the binding hole are indented to avoid the hole, but occasionally (where the hole is indicated in my edition), a character is inserted into the narrow space before the hole.

I feel quite sure that -nāma grāmagrāmaM in line 18 is dittography, where the scribe engraved grāma, then skipped believing he was still at nāma and re-engraved grāma. Hultzsch 411 believes otherwise and thinks grāma-grāma is deliberately used, meaning perhaps a large village or a chief village. He points out a parallel in line 18 of the Peṇukapaṟu grant of Jayasiṁha I (where, however, the original editor of that grant, Fleet, deems the repetition to be dittography).

Reported in 9A/1921-222 with some further details at 96-974. Edited from inked impressions by E. Hultzsch (), with facsimilesA photograph of the seal is included in the plate showing the seal of the Niḍupaṟu grant of Jayasiṁha I, between pages 56 and 57. and an abstract of the contents. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Hultzsch's edition with his facsimiles.
